title: How to Clear a Green Pool Fast: Step-by-Step Recovery Guide
excerpt: Came home to a green swamp instead of a sparkling pool? Don't panic. Learn the exact steps to transform your green pool back to crystal clear water in just a few days.

author.name: Pool Care Experts
author.bio: Our team of certified pool technicians has over 20 years of experience maintaining pools across the Phoenix Valley.

content:
Why Pools Turn Green (And It Happens Fast in Arizona)

A green pool is the result of algae growth – microscopic plants that thrive in warm, inadequately sanitized water. In Arizona's climate, conditions are perfect for algae: intense heat, abundant sunlight, and warm water temperatures. A pool can go from clear to swamp-green in as little as 24-48 hours if chlorine levels drop too low.

Common Causes of Green Pools:

  • Equipment malfunction (broken pump or filter)
  • Vacation or extended absence without maintenance
  • Storm or dust storm contamination
  • Improper chemical balance
  • Phosphate buildup feeding algae growth

Assess Your Pool: How Green Is It?

Before starting treatment, determine your algae severity level:

Light Green (Early Stage)

  • Water has a slight green tint
  • You can see the pool floor clearly
  • Treatment time: 1-2 days

Medium Green (Moderate Algae)

  • Water is cloudy green
  • You can barely see the pool floor
  • Treatment time: 3-5 days

Dark Green/Black (Severe Algae Bloom)

  • Water is opaque dark green or black
  • Cannot see into the water at all
  • Treatment time: 7-10 days (may consider drain and refill)

Step-by-Step Green Pool Recovery Process

Step 1: Remove Large Debris (30 minutes)

Use a leaf rake or skimmer net to remove leaves, branches, and any visible debris. Don't worry about getting everything – you'll handle the rest later. This prevents your filter from getting overwhelmed.

Pro Tip: Don't use your automatic pool cleaner yet. Algae can clog it, and you want to shock the pool first.

Step 2: Test and Balance Water Chemistry (15 minutes)

You need accurate starting numbers:

  • pH: Should be between 7.2-7.6. Use pH decreaser if it's high.
  • Alkalinity: Target 80-120 ppm. Adjust if needed before treating algae.
  • Chlorine: Will likely be zero or very low – that's why you have algae.

Why this matters: Shock treatment (high chlorine) works best in properly balanced water. High pH reduces chlorine effectiveness significantly.

Step 3: Brush the Entire Pool (20-30 minutes)

This is crucial and often skipped. Brush every surface vigorously:

  • Walls from top to bottom
  • Floor in overlapping patterns
  • Steps and benches
  • Around lights and fittings

Brushing breaks up algae colonies and releases them into the water where chemicals can kill them. Algae can cling tightly to surfaces and resist chemical treatment.

Step 4: Shock the Pool (SLAM Method)

SLAM stands for Shock Level And Maintain. This is the most critical step.

Calculate Your Shock Amount:

  • Light green: 2 lbs of shock per 10,000 gallons
  • Medium green: 3 lbs per 10,000 gallons
  • Dark green: 4-5 lbs per 10,000 gallons

Best Shock Product: Calcium hypochlorite (cal-hypo) is most effective. Liquid chlorine works but requires more volume. Avoid stabilized shock for this purpose.

Shocking Process:

  1. Shock in the evening after sunset (UV rays degrade chlorine)
  2. Add shock around the perimeter of the pool
  3. Brush the pool again immediately after adding shock
  4. Run your pump continuously (24 hours) during treatment
  5. Never add shock through the skimmer

Step 5: Run Your Filter Continuously

Keep your filter running 24/7 during the treatment process. This is not the time to worry about your electric bill – stopping the pump allows algae to resettle and grow.

Filter Maintenance During Treatment:

  • Sand filter: Backwash when pressure rises 8-10 psi above normal
  • Cartridge filter: Clean daily during heavy treatment
  • DE filter: Backwash and recharge as pressure increases

Your filter will work overtime catching dead algae. Expect to clean or backwash frequently – this is normal and necessary.

Step 6: Test and Maintain Chlorine Levels

This is where most people fail at green pool recovery. You must maintain high chlorine levels continuously:

  • Test chlorine levels twice daily (morning and evening)
  • Keep free chlorine at shock level (10-12 ppm) until algae is dead
  • Add more shock if levels drop below 10 ppm
  • Continue brushing daily

Step 7: Address Stubborn Algae

If after 48 hours your pool isn't improving, you may need additional help:

Add Algaecide:

While shock is the primary killer, algaecide can help with resistant algae:

  • Use a quality copper-based algaecide for green algae
  • Follow dosage instructions carefully
  • Add after the initial shock treatment, not at the same time

Consider Phosphate Remover:

Algae feeds on phosphates. If you have recurring algae issues, phosphate removal can help prevent future blooms.

Step 8: Vacuum to Waste

Once the water begins to clear (you can see the bottom), vacuum the pool:

  • Set your multiport valve to "Waste" (bypasses the filter)
  • Vacuum slowly to avoid stirring up settled debris
  • Monitor water level and refill as needed
  • This removes dead algae instead of sending it through your filter

If you have a cartridge filter, vacuum normally but clean the cartridges immediately after.

Step 9: Final Cleanup and Balance

When your water is clear:

  1. Give your filter a thorough cleaning
  2. Test all chemistry parameters
  3. Adjust pH, alkalinity, and calcium hardness to normal ranges
  4. Bring chlorine down to normal levels (3-5 ppm)
  5. Resume normal filtration schedule

Preventing Future Green Pool Situations

Maintain Proper Chlorine Levels

The single best prevention is consistent sanitization:

  • Test chlorine 2-3 times per week
  • Maintain 3-5 ppm free chlorine
  • Use stabilizer (cyanuric acid) to protect chlorine from UV breakdown

Vacation Preparation

Going away? Prepare your pool:

  • Shock the pool before leaving
  • Clean filter and empty baskets
  • Add a floater with chlorine tablets
  • Consider a pool sitter or service for extended trips

Maintain Your Equipment

  • Run your pump adequate hours (10-12 in summer)
  • Keep your filter clean and functioning
  • Address equipment problems immediately

When to Call a Professional

Sometimes DIY isn't the best approach:

  • Extremely dark or black water: May be more cost-effective to drain and refill
  • Repeated green pool issues: Underlying problem needs diagnosis
  • Equipment not working: May need repairs before chemical treatment works
  • Limited time or physical ability: Recovery is labor-intensive

Cost Comparison: DIY vs. Professional

DIY Recovery Costs (Average 20,000-gallon pool):

  • Shock (cal-hypo): $40-60
  • Algaecide: $20-30
  • pH decreaser: $10-15
  • Test kit or strips: $15-30
  • Total: $85-135

Professional Service:

  • Green pool cleanup: $200-500 depending on severity
  • Includes chemicals, labor, and equipment
  • Faster results (often 24-48 hours)

Conclusion: Prevention is Easier Than Recovery

Clearing a green pool requires time, effort, and patience – but it's absolutely doable. The key is maintaining high chlorine levels continuously while running your filter 24/7 and brushing daily. Most pools can be recovered in 3-5 days with diligent treatment.

However, the best approach is prevention. Regular testing, proper chemical maintenance, and functioning equipment will keep your pool sparkling and prevent you from ever dealing with a green swamp again. In Arizona's climate, a little neglect can lead to big problems quickly – but consistent maintenance keeps your pool beautiful year-round.
